unnormalised: So, I was helping my cousin, Priya, prep for her govt. job applications and the whole ID thing became a bit of a headache. She’s applying for a clerk position, and each form needed a different ID. Some wanted her Aadhar No. 2345-6789-0123, others needed her Voter ID (EPIC No. XYZ1234567).
normalised: So, I was helping my cousin, Priya, prep for her government job applications and the whole I-D thing became a bit of a headache. She’s applying for a clerk position, and each form needed a different I-D. Some wanted her Aadhar number two three four five dash six seven eight nine dash zero one two three, others needed her Voter I-D (E-P-I-C number X-Y-Z one two three four five six seven).

unnormalised: Then came the education part. They needed her roll number from 12th board exams – a string of digits like 12345/2018, and then the registration no. from her B.Com degree – something like REG/2021/ABC/007 from Delhi University. It felt like a never-ending stream of numbers and codes! And God forbid if you mess up one digit – application rejected!
normalised: Then came the education part. They needed her roll number from twelfth board exams – a string of digits like one two three four five slash two thousand and eighteen, and then the registration number from her B-Com degree – something like R-E-G slash two thousand and twenty one slash A-B-C slash zero zero seven from Delhi University. It felt like a never-ending stream of numbers and codes! And God forbid if you mess up one digit – application rejected!

unnormalised: What I learned is, keep a very organized record. Make a digital copy and physical copy. Also, remember that the format matters. For example, some forms accept "Aadhaar No. 234567890123" while others only allow "2345-6789-0123". It's crazy but that's how it is. Double-check everything before hitting 'submit', or as my grandma says, "Measure twice, cut once!".
normalised: What I learned is, keep a very organized record. Make a digital copy and physical copy. Also, remember that the format matters. For example, some forms accept "Aadhaar number two three four five six seven eight nine zero one two three" while others only allow "two three four five dash six seven eight nine dash zero one two three". It's crazy but that's how it is. Double-check everything before hitting 'submit', or as my grandma says, "Measure twice, cut once!".
